722896f.text:
Riverside Park: The Soldiers and Sailors Monument located on Riverside Drive at West 89th Street. Memorial
Day Servies are held tnere annually.
About 1905

722897f-a.text:
Riverside Park at West 89th Street, showing the Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Monument, erected in 1902 to commemorate the valor of the Union soldiers in the Civil War. Paul Duboy was the sculptor.
About 1910
Gift Of Urbrock Collection

722891f-b.text:
Riverside Park:
Riverside Drive, north from 86th Street. The Columbia Yacht Club is in the foreground.
April 29, 1934

P.L. Sperr.

(2 & 3)

Two similar views at the same date. The cylindrical monument is the Soldiers and Sailors, on the west side of the Drive at 89th Street.
April 29, 1934
P.L. Sperr

722893f-a.text:
Riverside Park: A set of 2 views in a generally northward direction from the Soldiers and Sailors Monument on the west side of the Drive at the head of West 89th Street. Buildings on the right, on the east side of the Drive, face this marginal park that skirts the North River; View
2 showing this aspect mainly.
June 16, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

722893f-b.text:
Riverside Park: A set of 2 views in a generally northward direction from the Soldiers and Sailors Monument on the west side of the Drive at the head of West 89th Street. Buildings on the right, on the east side of the Drive, face this marginal park that skirts the North River; View
2 showing this aspect mainly.
June 16, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

722898f.text:
Riverside Park, at West 89th Street, showing the Soldiers and Sailors Monument. It was erected in 1902 to commemorate the valor of those who died in defense of the Union during the Civil War. Paul E. Muboy is the sculptor. It is made of white marble in the form of a small circular Greek Temple with a peristyle of twelve Corinthian columns.
1936
W.P.A. Photo
Federal Writers Project

722722f-a.text:
140 to 147 Riverside Drive, east side, north from W. 88th to 87th Streets, showing a block front of private residences (built in 1896 by Henry Cook, architect) that are about to be replaced by a modern 18 story apartment house at a cost of 92,500,000. An account to this effect is in the New York Times of August 7, 1938. Included in this plan are 4 additional dwellings, No. 351 W. 86th Street (right of No. 1) and No's. 348,50 and 52 N. 87th Street (not seen) Dr. John A. Harriss, former department commissioner of police,occupied for years Io. 140, the structure at the N.W. corner of W. 85th Street. No.2 is a southward view from a point slightly to the north
of W. 87th Street.
August 15, 1938.
Views 1 and 2
P.L. Sperr

722722f-b.text:
140 to 147 Riverside Drive, east side, north from W. 88th to 87th Streets, showing a block front of private residences (built in 1896 by Henry Cook, architect) that are about to be replaced by a modern 18 story apartment house at a cost of 92,500,000. An account to this effect is in the New York Times of August 7, 1938. Included in this plan are 4 additional dwellings, No. 351 W. 86th Street (right of No. 1) and No's. 348,50 and 52 N. 87th Street (not seen) Dr. John A. Harriss, former department commissioner of police,occupied for years Io. 140, the structure at the N.W. corner of W. 85th Street. No.2 is a southward view from a point slightly to the north
of W. 87th Street.
August 15, 1938.
Views 1 and 2
P.L. Sperr

Brown Brothers.
